text.p: Fortis, the Dutch-Belgian banking and insurance group touted as a likely buyer of Dutch bank ABN AMRO's MeesPierson investment banking unit, said on Wednesday it is constantly looking for opportunities.
But a spokesman for Fortis repeated the group's previous line that it did not comment on individual cases.
Analysts have said Fortis, jointly owned by Fortis AG and Fortis AMEV, is keen to buy MeesPierson, which ABN AMRO is negotiating to sell.
"We have a growth strategy. We are constantly on the lookout for opportunities," Fortis spokesman Ate Bootsma told Reuters.
ABN AMRO said on Tuesday it was in discussions after being approached by a number of parties interested in the unit.
The Dutch bank has declined to reveal with whom it is negotiating or when an announcement might be made on the sale, which analysts expect to raise up to 2.5 billion guilders.
They said Fortis was keen to add investment and corporate banking to its retail banking interests, which include VSB Bank in the Netherlands.
Dutch co-operative bank Rabobank has also been mentioned as a possible bidder but a spokesman on Tuesday said Rabobank was not involved in the bidding process.
